script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Marcus, hi Mom. I see he's here for breathing trouble?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yeah, he's been coughing a lot the past two days, especially at night. And today he's wheezing. I've been giving him his albuterol every four hours.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay. Let me just review his medications real quick. He's on albuterol as needed, Flovent twice daily, Singulair at night, and Zyrtec for allergies. Is that still current?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, that's right. The albuterol is the inhaler with the spacer, two puffs. Flovent is also two puffs morning and night. Singulair is the five milligram chewable at bedtime. And Zyrtec is the liquid, one teaspoon, I give that in the morning.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect. And he's been taking all of those consistently?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, we're pretty good about it. I have a chart on the fridge.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's great. Marcus, can you tell me how you're feeling? Is it hard to breathe?

script.speaker: child
script.text: My chest feels tight. And I keep coughing.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm sorry buddy, that doesn't feel good. Let me listen to you.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, I can hear some wheezing in both lungs, more on the right side. He's moving air okay but definitely having some bronchospasm. Let's do a breathing treatment here and see how he responds.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should we increase his Flovent? This seems to happen every time the weather changes.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a good thought. What dose is his Flovent right now?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It's the 44 microgram one. Two puffs twice a day.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Given that he's having more frequent flares, I think we should step him up to the 110 microgram strength. Same thing, two puffs twice daily, but stronger dose.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. And should we keep doing the albuterol every four hours?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: For the next two to three days, yes, you can do albuterol every four to six hours as needed. Once he's back to baseline, go back to using it only when he needs it.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What about a steroid burst? Last time they gave him that prednisone liquid.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to hold off on that for now. Let's see how he does with the increased Flovent and regular albuterol. If he's not better in 48 hours or gets worse, then we'll add the oral steroid.

script.speaker: child
script.text: I don't like that medicine. It tastes bad.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I know, it's not fun. Hopefully we won't need it. The nurse is going to come give you a breathing treatment now, and you should feel a lot better after.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: So to summarize, we're increasing the Flovent to the 110, keeping everything else the same, albuterol every four to six hours for now, and call if he's not better in two days?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Exactly right. And call sooner if he's working harder to breathe, breathing fast, or the albuterol isn't lasting four hours.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Got it. Should I schedule a follow up?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, let's have him come back in two weeks so we can see how the new Flovent dose is working. We might keep him there or adjust again depending on how he does.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you, Doctor. Say thank you, Marcus.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Thank you.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You're welcome. Hang in there, buddy.
